awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Skull Growth and Biomechanical Constraints on Molar Emergence in Primates
awd_abstract_narration:
Human life history is unique among living primates. Humans grow slowly and have long lifespans coupled with short inter-birth intervals, resulting in fast reproductive rates. Among primates, there is a strong relationship between life history and the age at which the first permanent molar emerges into the mouth. Paleoanthropologists use this relationship to probe the antiquity of the unique human life history profile, but exactly why molar emergence varies and is closely associated with life history remains unclear. This study will examine molar emergence as part of a developing, functionally integrated chewing system, to provide a model for contextualizing variation in the timing of molar emergence among primates. It will also contribute to understanding the close association between molar emergence and life history. The project will yield a rich public database of 3D primate skull growth with relevance to the study of craniofacial growth and molar impaction, and support public science outreach and training of graduate and undergraduate students in a STEM field. 

Molars function with the jaws and chewing muscles to break down food. Developmental coordination among these parts of the chewing system is critical for food ingestion throughout life. In adult primates, the configuration of the chewing system constrains the position of molars to avoid damage to the temporomandibular joint during chewing. Using 3D coordinate data from cross-sectional ontogenetic samples of primate skulls (n = 18 species; 1,182 specimens) this study will determine if the position of molar emergence is constrained in the same manner, thereby regulating the timing of molar emergence. This research will examine how ontogenetic changes in the configuration of the chewing system drive variation in molar emergence schedules among primates, and may suggest that life history is closely associated with molar emergence ages through its influence on facial growth rates. It will further suggest that selection for shorter faces and a prolonged growth schedule in the lineage leading to humans would have had the concomitant effect of delaying molar emergence.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The age at which the first permanent molar tooth (M1) emerges into the mouth is an indicator of a species’ pace of growth and development. Across primates, age at M1 emergence is strongly correlated to life-history variables, such as age at weaning, age at first reproduction, and longevity. This relationship allows for the reconstruction of these important life-history parameters in fossil humans. The mechanism responsible for modulating molar emergence age is unknown, however. Two unanswered questions stand in the way of a more complete understanding of the timing of molar emergence in primates: (2) What factors influence variation in ages at M1 emergence among primates? and (1) Why is age at M1 emergence closely associated with fundamental aspects of a species’ life history? The aim of this project was to generate a growth model that accurately predicts the position and timing of molar emergence using current knowledge of chewing biomechanics.

Molars are part of an integrated system in which they function, together with the jaws and chewing muscles, to break down food. This chewing system is configured to avoid dislocation of the jaw joint (i.e., the temporomandibular joint (TMJ)) during biting and chewing. One key aspect of chewing system configuration is the position of molars in the jaws: the last molar’s position is constrained so that it is always in front of the muscles that close the jaws because biting behind this point produces tensile forces at the TMJ, potentially damaging the joint. Molars are therefore always positioned along the jaws such that TMJ damage is mitigated during chewing. It is reasonable to assume that the same constraints on molar position exist throughout growth. Using three-dimensional coordinate data from growth samples of 1258 skulls, representing 21 primate species, this research tested the hypothesis that the location and timing of molar emergence is constrained to avoid damage to the TMJ throughout growth.

Results indicate that for all species examined, all molars emerged in a predictable position to safeguard the TMJ from damage during chewing. The results also indicate that the rate at which space is made available in the jaws during growth is key in determining the timing of molar emergence. Identifying this developmental constraint across taxa that vary in craniofacial configuration and timing of molar emergence suggests that ontogenetic changes in the configuration of the chewing system regulate variation in molar emergence schedules among primates.

This research has generated a rich taxonomically diverse database of skull growth data to test hypotheses specific to this project as well as for future research on the growth of the primate skull. This research is currently being prepared for publication and the data will be made publicly available with these publications. The results of this project have been presented at one national and one international conference. Furthermore, the project has been presented, as part of an outreach program run through the Institute of Human Origins, to K-12 students as a way of understanding life-history evolution in the human lineage. 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: Halszka Glowacka
